content.text: AMNESIA
Written by
Ryan Jae
RyanJ0894@gmail.com
FADE IN:
CLOSE ON rushing water off riverbanks. It crashes into rocks violently.
FROM FURTHER OUT
The river is beautiful, even at night.
ZOOM IN on a toy sail boat drifting down stream peacefully.
FROM HIGH ARIEL VIEW: we see the river leads to a waterfall off a cliff ahead. The sail boat is heading straight for it. It reaches near the edge.
CLOSE ON sailboat, just as it goes over the edge
ALL SOUND DROPS OUT
Then [BANG!] Sounds a gun in the background.
CUT TO:
There’s quick close shots of dark woods, a gun in hand waving, blood splattered shoes pacing erratically.
CLOSE ON Frankie, 18, good looking, POPULAR, Caucasian high school quarterback. He’s wearing a black tuxedo but is sweating bullets. He’s crying and can’t stay still.

dialogue: This is your fault! Your fault!

content.text: CLOSE ON Derek, 18 unpopular African American “skater kid” lying on the ground in severe pain. He too is dressed in a tuxedo. He’s holding his bloody leg tightly.

dialogue: What the hell are you talking about!?
I didn’t wanna hurt anyone. I needed help!
We were supposed to be friends. But who gives a shit, right?
You’re sick bro! You DO need help.
Yea? You didn't do shit.. Take responsibility for your actions! I was doing fine. You're the one!
I’m the victim. Not you. Me!

content.text: Derek's silence speaks volumes as his facial expression begins to show empathy. He looks down shamefully.
Derek looks up.

dialogue: I know what happened to all those women.

content.text: Frankie holds a smile for a beat, then
CLOSE ON
His face as all emotion drains before our eyes and he says

dialogue: Those poor bitches never saw it coming.

content.text: DISSOLVE TO:
I/E. CAR - RURAL ROAD - DAY
FROM HIGH AERIAL VIEW: a car drives down a road with woods on each side. It’s a beautiful scene, like a puzzle picture.

dialogue: Some people say there’s beauty in everything. And happy endings... Well, they exist. It’s all in perspective they say.

content.text: INSIDE CAR
BRENDA, a mid 40’s attractive African American woman with cuts and light bruising on her face drives alone. She has bags under her eyes and looks like she’s been crying.
BACK TO AERIAL VIEW
The car is approaching a large building.
CLOSER ON a front gated entrance with an armed guard attendant.

dialogue: Some things are ugly. And some endings aren’t happy.

content.text: CUT TO:

scene_info.location: MAXIMUM SECURITY FACILITY - VISITATION ROOM - MOMENTS LATER

content.text: The room is clean, and practically empty with the exception of a small table and a box of tissue in Brenda’s hand.
She sits at the table across from a straggly worn down looking woman, who rocks in her seat with her hands under the table. Her hair is messy, in her face.
Brenda takes a deep breathe and then exhales with her eyes closed.

dialogue: If I would’ve known all those years ago how things would turn out... I wonder if I would’ve made the same choices? I ask myself that a lot lately.

content.text: A tear rolls down Brenda’s cheek, she sniffles.

dialogue: I knew something wasn’t right but it was too late. I ran out of options and I had to make a decision. I had to do what was right. I had to.
I had no choice. You understand... don’t you?

content.text: Brenda smiles through tears.

scene_info.location: MAXIMUM SECURITY FACILITY - VISITATION ROOM - MOMENTS LATER

content.text: The straggly woman doesn’t react. After a few moments, Brenda wipes her face and stops crying.
DISSOLVE TO:
A football sails through the air into the hands of a wide receiver.

dialogue: It’s still hard to believe any of this is real.

content.text: There’s players in red and blue practice jerseys, COACH DAVIS, tall heavy set African American man in his 50’s and COACH STANLEY, 30’s muscular Caucasian man are on the side lines.
High school kids walk around near the field while head cheerleader, JILL, a beautifully flawless Caucasian female stands with other cheerleaders on the side lines.
Jill looks to the field, waves and blows a kiss to Frankie, standing in the huddle with his teammates as a leader.

dialogue: First they’re friends, then they hate each other and then amnesia... A clean slate.

content.text: Frankie is about to call the play but pauses, looking to the outskirts of the field.

ZOOMING IN just outside the end zone to DEREK, hanging out with friends, DREW, a short Hispanic male, DAN, a thin Caucasian male, and Derek’s girlfriend CARRIE, an attractive yet understated dirty blonde. Other kids are around them as well but not a part of their click. Nearly everyone in the area has a skate board in hand or on the ground.

Frankie’s teammate, BRAD, 18, clean cut popular African American wide receiver nudges him and BILLY, tall athletic Caucasian tight end, as they all look down field toward Derek. The rest of his teammates follow his gaze and nod, smiling deviously.
CUT TO:
BACK TO DEREK
Derek’s laughing with Carrie.

dialogue: But erasing memories doesn’t change what happened and hiding the truth doesn’t last forever.

content.text: Derek, Carrie and friends begin to kick a hackie sack back and forth.
CUT TO:
BACK TO FRANKIE
Frankie and his teammates are exiting the huddle on field. They get into position.

dialogue: It’s a Band-Aid on a gunshot wound.

content.text: The ball is hiked to Frankie. He back peddles looking about.

dialogue: It may stop the bleeding for a second or two. But...

content.text: Frankie launches the football deep down field. Brad runs hard for it.
CUT TO:
BACK TO DEREK
Derek and Carrie face each other. Carrie looks past Derek, her eyes grow large.
Brad CRASHES into Derek, plowing over him as he catches the pass. Derek lays there looking up angrily at Brad.
Brad laughs under his breathe as he extends his hand to Derek.

dialogue: My bad bro. Didn’t see you there.

content.text: Derek slaps his hand away.
The football players, a few bystanders and some of the cheerleaders BURST out in laughter. Brad jogs off laughing as well.
Humiliation is written all over Derek’s face as Carrie helps him up.
Derek glares at Frankie from across the field.
CLOSE ON Frankie smiling. He shrugs his shoulders with his hands out, insincerely gesturing it was an accident.
Derek shakes his head and walks in the other direction.
CUT TO:

SHERIFF CARTER, mid 40’s, strong looking man, walks through the busy police station with a look of determination on his face. He goes over to the coffee pot and pours himself a cup. He turns and walks into:
Sheriff Carter shuts the door. He goes over to his desk, sets his coffee mug down and unlocks the bottom drawer. He searches through his files.

CLOSE ON file labeled “Widow Killings”. Sheriff Carter pulls out the file. He takes a seat and opens it, taking out an envelope with several crime scene photos. He spreads them across the desk and sips his coffee.

dialogue: What am I missing? Talk to me.

content.text: He separates a picture of the first victim’s left hand with severed ring finger, then searches through the pile. He pulls out similar angled photos of other victims.

dialogue: Inexperienced maybe? But why take a finger? Souvenir? Or something more?

content.text: CUT TO:
We look over a small suburban town. The streets are lined with trees. Kids are outside playing in their yards and people seem happy. It’s peaceful.

The news is starting in the background. A more relaxed Brenda, sits on the couch with her best friend and neighbor JEWELS, mid 40’s, attractive Caucassion woman. Brenda grabs the TV remote and turns up the volume.
We see them watching the News Report
“NEWS REPORTER” The murder count is now up to three, officially making this a serial killer case.
Brenda and Jewels look at one another.

“NEWS REPORTER” (CONT’D) It seems this “Widow Butcher” has stuck to the pattern so far. The victims have all been brutally stabbed to death and mutilated. Motive for these sadistic acts is still unknown. Authorities advise everyone, especially widowed women to be extra cautious, even more so after dark. No major leads have been confirmed at this time. I’m Kathy Kirk with the six o’clock news.
Brenda turns the television off.

dialogue: Can you believe something like this... Here?
I know, I’ve been scared to leave the house.
When Frankie’s father was here I didn't worry about anything. But now... You always think it could never happen where you live. Now not only is it happening but we’re the psycho’s prime targets.
I get the chills thinking about it. I just hope he gets caught... SOON. In the meantime we’ll just have each other's backs.

content.text: Brenda gets up out of her seat.

dialogue: I’m gonna make some coffee. Can I get you a cup?

content.text: Brenda walks off and Jewels follows.
Brenda begins making the coffee.

dialogue: Any improvements with Derek in school?

content.text: Brenda smirks.

dialogue: Lets just say he’s not exactly an honor student, which is a shame because he’s so smart.
Yeah, Derek’s way too smart to be struggling in school. There’s gotta be something he likes in school or something to motivate him.
I wish, but I’ve tried everything I could think of. He doesn’t like sports, he loves music but says he doesn’t wanna taint it...

content.text: CUT TO:
DEREK, makes his way down the stairs.
Derek stops at the bottom of the stairs, easedropping just outside the kitchen.

dialogue: I hate to say that Derek’s a lost cause but.. Ever since his father passed, he just won’t listen to me. I don’t know how you do it as a single mother, Jewels. I’d kill for Derek to have Frankie’s discipline.

content.text: CUT TO:
Derek shakes his head as he stands listening.

dialogue: Oh don’t say that Brenda. Derek’s a good kid with a great mom. Apple doesn’t fall far from the tree.

content.text: A beat.

dialogue: He just needs some guidance. I’ll ask Frankie to talk to him. Maybe he can motivate him. They used to be best friends.
Would you? I think if Derek had a positive influence like Frankie in his life again, maybe it could make a difference. We couldn’t separate them when they were kids. I don’t know what happened.
They probably just grew apart. Happens all the time.

content.text: Derek walks into the kitchen.
Derek kisses her on the cheek. Brenda looks guilty.

dialogue: How are you Derek? How was school?
Oh, just another day at the office. You know how it is.

content.text: Jewels smiles at Derek as he gets a bottled water out of the refrigerator.

dialogue: Well I guess I’ll leave you two alone. Wouldn't wanna interrupt what I'm sure was a very important discussion.
I’ll be home in an hour or so mother.
Okay, try not to be too late. I’m starting dinner soon.

content.text: Derek exits shutting the door behind him.
The door bursts back open and Derek sticks his head in,
startling Brenda and Jewels.

dialogue: Just wanted to say, Frankie and I didn’t grow apart. To be totally honest, I think he’s a dick. No offense Mrs. J.

content.text: Jewels flashes an awkward smile.

dialogue: I’ll be back in an hour or so mother.

content.text: Derek exits, shutting the door.
A beat as Brenda and Jewels look at each other with discomfort.
FROM THE SIDELINES
We see Frankie standing in the center of the huddle out on the field giving direction. He finishes calling the play. Coaches Davis and Stanley watch.
The guys get into position on the field to run the play in their scrimmage. The ball is hiked to Frankie. He back peddles a few yards and zips a perfect pass to Brad.

dialogue: That’s what I'm talking about Frankie! Keep it up! We’re winning state this year.

content.text: DISSOLVE TO:
Frankie walks over to his locker. CLOSE ON abs with a towel wrapped around his waist.
He takes his clothes out of his locker and begins getting dressed.
Frankie’s good friend and teammate, Billy approaches fully dressed with a backpack off one shoulder.

dialogue: Nice work out there on the field Frankie.
Hey did you finish that English paper?
Nah man, my Trig teacher is killing me with work. I haven’t had the chance. You think you can help me out?
I just need to hold on to it for like a day bro; and I’ll give it back. Is that cool?
Nah, that’s not cool Billy. You know I can’t let you cheat.
Aw come on Frankie. I’m struggling here.
Look Billy, I can help you out, fill you in on what you need to know. You’ll breeze through it. It’ll be easy.
Oh, it’s all good Billy. We’re teammates.

content.text: Frankie takes Billy under his arm, walking with him.

dialogue: Okay, now what parts have you read so far?

content.text: CUT TO:
FROM HIGH IN THE TREES the camera pans through the thick vegetation of the woods. It’s beautiful, vibrant and full of life.
With their backs to us, Derek sits with his good friend, Drew, at the edge of the riverbanks near a cliff overlooking the water.
It would look like a postcard if they weren’t smoking weed.
Derek takes a big drag from the nicely rolled skinny blunt.

dialogue: That is fucked up Derek. But she probably didn’t mean it the way you took it man. I’ve met your mom. She seems all right. I hardly ever see my mom.

content.text: Derek passes the blunt to Drew.

dialogue: Derek I’m telling you dude, she just wants the best for you and she thinks you can, and should do better in school...

content.text: Derek looks at Drew and smiles peculiarly.

dialogue: I think that weed’s getting to your head. You seem smarter.

content.text: Drew laughs and punches Derek in the arm.

dialogue: All I’m saying is you shouldn’t sell yourself short. You’re a smart ass dude and it would suck to let your potential go to waste.
Okay, no more smoking for you.

content.text: Derek takes the blunt from Drew. They laugh, then sit there in silence for a while.

dialogue: Have you ever had a moment that makes you question everything you’ve ever known?
Strange question. But, no I don’t think so. What’s going on?
There’s just a lot about myself and my life that I didn’t know.

content.text: Drew reaches for the joint and Derek passes it to him.
Drew takes a big drag. Derek begins to get angry the more he speaks.

dialogue: Like my dad had a sister; Aunt Stacy. My mother said she died in a car accident a long time ago.
They didn’t tell me. They never told me anything. Always in the dark about my own so called “family.”
Then she acts like she wants me to be someone else.

content.text: BEAT.
Drew passes the blunt to Derek.

dialogue: The thing that bothers me the most is that she thinks the world of that fraud, Frankie.

content.text: CLOSE ON blunt in Derek’s hand.
CLOSE ON joint burning his finger.
DISSOLVE TO:
Frankie enters. Brenda and Jewels are at the table.

dialogue: I hope you don’t mind me just walking in Mrs. B. I heard my mom from outside.
Oh no, it’s okay. You know you’re welcome here.
Thanks Mrs. B. That’s nice to know.

content.text: They all smile at one another.

dialogue: But you should start locking your door... With this psychopath running around town and all.
You’re right. Lets try getting that point across to Derek.
Anyway, to what do we owe this visit?
Oh, I just wanted to ask mom; uh, do you want me to start dinner?
No, I’ll be home in a bit. But thanks for asking. How was practice?
It was good. The coaches worked us hard, but it’ll pay off come playoff time.
That’s exactly the attitude I’d expect.

content.text: Frankie flashes a smile.

dialogue: I’ll get out of your hair now I guess. Don’t stay out too late mom.

content.text: Jewels smiles. Frankie exits.
Jewels’ smile lingers.

dialogue: Everyone always says don’t judge a book by its cover. But somehow, some way, we still do.

content.text: DISSOLVE TO:
Sheriff Carter is on the phone.
Carter is annoyed.

dialogue: Yes sir, but I have reason to--

content.text: Carter begins to get frustrated.
Carter throws his arms up in the air and leans back in his chair.

dialogue: But the DNA we have doesn’t match anything in our system or the FBI’s because this guy’s never been convicted of any crimes. He’s never even been arrested.

content.text: Carter rolls his eyes. It’s clear that he isn’t getting anywhere.

dialogue: But Sargent, I’m telling you he’s new to this and we have his profile all wrong--

content.text: Carter slams his hands down on the desk and rises to his feat.

dialogue: The FBI? But the FBI doesn’t even know this town! I know the people; This is my case.

content.text: Sheriff waits silently, mocking him with his hand, mouthing what his hand gestures.

dialogue: If you say so. You’re the boss.

content.text: Derek enters through the front door. Brenda sits in the living room reading a book with the television on mute. She nods hello to Derek without looking up from her book.
Derek heads to
Derek walks to the fridge and opens it.

dialogue: There’s some pizza in the oven.

content.text: Derek pulls the pizza out of the oven. He sets it on the counter. He opens the cabinet above and takes out a plate.
Brenda enters.
Derek takes a bite out of his pizza, nodding yes with his mouth full.

dialogue: You seem to be hanging out with Drew more.

content.text: Derek sets his pizza down.

dialogue: Not that I don’t love this mother- son moment we seem to be having, but what’s up?
Well it’s about the conversation you overheard earlier.
Say no more. It’s okay. I accept your apology. Now let’s just put it all behind us.
Well Derek I’m afraid it’s not as simple as that.
I’m sorry you had to hear what I said the way you did, but I’m not sorry I said it.
Oh this is not happening. Why did I ever listen to Drew?

content.text: A beat, Brenda is confused for a second.

dialogue: What? Anyway, all I’m saying is you could be a little more responsible. Maybe even a little more social.
Like who? Socially responsible like who mother?
Oh whatever mother. You’re referring to Frankie aren’t you?

content.text: A beat.

dialogue: Yes Derek., I am. Is that so bad? I just want the best for you. You’re so smart, but ever since your father passed--

content.text: Derek holds his hand up, silencing Brenda. Brenda looks both shocked and appalled.

dialogue: If you want me to be more like Frankie, the son you never had, that’s your prerogative. But don’t bring dad into this. You don’t know Frankie like I do. You should be careful around him.
Derek that’s ridiculous. This is Frankie we’re talking about.

content.text: A beat. Brenda is taken back.
Derek, frustrated, shakes his head. He takes a few slices of pizza and puts them on his plate, and exits the room.
Brenda stands there confused.
Brenda sits on the couch. She’s upset, trying to hold back tears as she speaks into the phone.

dialogue: I’m just so drained. Losing JEFF in such a violent way with no warning... It’s been the hardest thing I’ve ever dealt with. But I’m trying to pick up the pieces of our lives.
I know Brenda, and you’re doing great.

content.text: Brenda exhales and wipes her teary eyes.

dialogue: I typically don’t ask because I know talking about it hurts, but did they ever get any new or helpful leads?
No not really. They officially ruled it a home break in that went wrong. But it doesn’t make sense because nothing was stolen. And why stab someone so many times in a simple robbery?

content.text: DISSOLVE TO:
The cafeteria is crowded with students.

dialogue: We live in a world divided into groups. Its not always racism as much as its place-ism. That’s what Jeff used to say. Putting people in their place.

content.text: Frankie hangs out with Brad, Billy, Jill and other friends at their “popular” table. Most of them are wearing letterman jackets.
Jill continues to smile and make physical contact with Frankie. Brad and Billy are paling around at the table.

dialogue: But what happens when someone can’t find their place? Even in a room full of people? I imagine that to be really and truly, lonely.

content.text: Across the cafeteria Derek sits with Drew, Dan, Carrie and a few other friends goofing around. Skate boards and helmets are scattered on the table with their lunches.
CUT TO:

Some students hang around as others leave. Frankie walks out with Brad and Billy. They give one another “bro” handshakes and fist bumps. They pass a convertible with its top down. Frankie tosses his bag into the passenger seat and hops over the door and into the driver seat. Brad and Billy wave and walk off.
Frankie notices a prescription bottle peaking out of his bag. He stares at it for a moment, pushes it back into the bag, then slowly rides off.
As Frankie reaches the end of the parking lot, Derek is on the curb, hoping on his skateboard. He skates off past Frankie. Frankie makes a quick right and catches up to him, slowing down beside him.
Derek is surprised, he gives no response.

dialogue: You need a ride home? I’m headed to the coffee shop.
Are you sure? I have plenty of room. You can toss your board in the back.
I’m sure dude. It’s a nice day. I could use the fresh air.
But my top’s down bro. You can catch some fresh air with me.

content.text: Derek hops off his skateboard abruptly. Frankie breaks next to him.

dialogue: Look Frankie. We’re not friends. Why pretend just because your mom wants you to?
I’m not pretending. We could be friends again.

content.text: Derek jumps back on his board and skates off.

dialogue: Don’t you think you’re being a little rude?

content.text: Frankie continues to follow Derek, driving along side him. Derek begins skating across the street but Frankie quickly makes a sharp turn cutting him off, nearly running into Derek.

dialogue: What the hell is your problem dude!

content.text: Frankie gets out of the car.

dialogue: Calm down Derek, I just wanna talk to you.
About what? We have nothing to talk about.

content.text: There’s a short beat as Frankie searches for something to say.
Derek rolls his eyes and begins turning away.

dialogue: Look Derek, I’m sorry about the other day on the football field. It wasn’t my idea but I shouldn’t have went along with it.

content.text: Derek stops and grins through his anger.

dialogue: Look Frankie, you may be viewed as Mr. Universe to all these dumb asses, but I know different. This facade, it won’t hold up forever.
So you think you know me, huh neighbor?
Yeah, I do. And sooner or later, everyone else will see you for who you really are. And all this will just fade away. Now go to the coffee shop.

content.text: Derek begins to turn away again. Frankie leans against his car door.

dialogue: Fade away? What would your mom think about that?

content.text: Derek stops.
Frankie shrugs.
Frankie stares back at Derek sternly.

dialogue: You better stay away from my mother Frankie.

content.text: They continue to stare each other down in uncomfortable silence.
CUT TO:
SHERIFF CARTER
Sits in his police car, far off in the distance.
Sheriff Carter POV:
Derek hops back on his skateboard and takes off.
SHERIFF CARTER (V.O.)? What the hell was that about?
CUT TO:
BACK TO FRANKIE
Frankie stands, arms folded watching Derek ride off.

dialogue: When Derek and Frankie started bumping heads more, it didn’t seem like a big deal at first. No one could’ve known...
At least that’s what I tell myself when I’m feeling guilty for not seeing it. Maybe if I would’ve noticed sooner...

content.text: Derek sits at the riverbanks alone smoking a joint. Drew comes walking up from behind holding a latte.
Derek looks back.

dialogue: I can’t stay long. Gotta get this latte to my mom. Let me hit that.

content.text: Derek passes the joint to Drew and Drew takes a hit.

dialogue: I ran into Frankie. Chilled with him for a sec. His friends are dicks.
What were you doing with Frankie?
Yeah, you know, like me and you are chillin’ right now.
What’s the big damn deal? Are you okay?
It’s my mother again. I don’t think she trusts me. She’s made it plain that she’d rather I was someone else and I just get this vibe from her lately. I know she’s been hiding stuff.
I don’t think its as sinister as your making it dude.

content.text: Beat.
You can see by Derek’s facial expression that he’s drifted into a mental space of nostalgia.

dialogue: I think a lot about how who we are actually has nothing to do with us. Who we are is deeper. Why we are... If a person is born different, can they change?
I watch the news and see all this about the widow killings and I wonder... I wonder if it was all inevitable? Was it already too late before a decision was even formed? Maybe it’s destiny.

content.text: Beat.

dialogue: Wow dude... Uhhh yeah. I gotta-- I gotta say that was disturbing.

content.text: Drew laughs lightly, but Derek’s face remains serious.

dialogue: What if it was me? What would you think?
Would you be surprised? Or would it be, like an epiphany?

content.text: Drew pauses, seeing the seriousness in Derek’s eyes before responding.

dialogue: Yes or no dude. Would you be surprised?

content.text: Drew is obviously afraid and becomes nervous.

dialogue: I’m leaving bro. Gotta get this drink to my mom.

content.text: Drew turns to walk away. Derek gets up and grabs Drew by the arm. Drew turns back.
CLOSE ON Drew’s face displaying his increasing fear.
CLOSE ON Derek’s face showing nearly no emotion.
They hold a stare, then Derek lets out a hearty laugh.

dialogue: You should’ve seen your fucking face man! You turned even whiter than normal!

content.text: Drew playfully pushes Derek.

dialogue: Don’t freak me out like that! You’re a fucking dick man.

content.text: Derek continues to laugh, mocking Drew’s expression.

dialogue: Whatever, I’m leaving. I gotta get this latte to my mom.
She’s gonna be pissed if it’s cold. I’ll talk to you at school tomorrow, asshole.

content.text: Drew turns and walks off. As Derek watches Drew leave his smile fades as his emotionless stare returns, like Jekyl & Hyde.

dialogue: We don’t always admit it but everyone needs someone. Derek always acted so tough. It was hard to see anything else. But he’s no different than me, you or anyone else..

content.text: CUT TO:
Derek is at his locker trading books out. Carrie, Dan and Drew are with him.

dialogue: It was really sick. I’m telling you, you have to see it. I’ll text you the link.
I won’t be able to stop thinkin’ about it until I see it now.
He’s easily excitable dude, trust me. It’s not that dope.
Okay.. Drew will be the judge.
I’m staying out of this one.

content.text: They all LAUGH.
A beat. The bell RINGS.

dialogue: Time to put on our thinking caps.
Bye babe, try to stay awake.

content.text: Derek kisses Carrie then turns and walks off.
Derek turns down the hallway. Ahead, Frankie leans against the wall by the classroom door. He watches Derek approach, staring him down, smiling.
Derek ignores him and enters the classroom.
DISSOLVE TO:
Derek sits at the riverbank smoking weed. There’s a RUSTLING in the bushes.
Derek stands up and turns around. Derek sees Sheriff Carter poking around the bushes in the distance.
Derek quickly tosses the joint from his mouth into the river and takes out his others from his pocket and hides them under a rock.
Sheriff Carter spots him and begins to approach. Derek tries to act normal.

dialogue: Oh it’s goin’. You mind me asking what you’re doing out here?
Oh, I come here a lot. I like to get away from everything... everyone and just think... you know?
I know it smells like sticky weed out here. That’s what I know. You been smoking son?
No Sir. That stuff’s bad news. Gateway drug I think they call it.
How’s your mom? I’ve been meaning to drop by to check on her.
Yeah? Good. How about that pretty neighbor friend of hers?

content.text: Derek smiles oddly, looking confused.

dialogue: Alright, glad to hear it. Tell them both I said hi.

content.text: Sheriff Carter tips his hat, turns and walks away.

dialogue: And Derek, don’t let me catch you smoking down here. This aint’t Colorado.
Oh, don’t worry Sheriff, you won’t ever catch me smoking.

content.text: Derek watches the Sheriff as he walks off. Then sits back down and pulls his other joints from under the rock. He lights and takes a hit. Suddenly a shadow of someone standing behind him appears. He practically spits out the joint into his hand and quickly rises to his feet.

dialogue: Sheriff, I’m really sorry. I’ve been so stressed

content.text: REVEAL: Frankie standing there

dialogue: What the hell? You stalking me? What do you want?
Nothing, I just wanted to see how you were doing?

content.text: Derek puts his joint back in his mouth, taking a few puffs.

dialogue: So have you thought about what I said earlier?
We have no friendship Frankie. We haven’t for a really long time now. Or did you bump your head?
You know as much as I do everyone needs someone Derek.
Really? Well you’re barking up the wrong tree, because I don’t need your needy ass. Call Jill or someone.

content.text: Derek shrugs, taking another hit.
Frankie stands awkwardly with his arms folded trying to hide his bruised ego when his attention drifts somewhere else.

dialogue: You know, I remember when we were kids hanging out down here. Do you still use that hiding place we had?

content.text: Frankie motions to a small cave covered by bushes and weeds.

dialogue: Nope. Haven’t used that spot in years.
Probably still has our old stuff in it.

content.text: Frankie begins walking towards the cave, along side the riverbank.
Derek tosses his joint and jogs up to him, grabbing his arm. Frankie stops angrily looking at Derek’s hand on his arm.

content.text: A beat. Drew walks over.
Drew pulls up a chair and sits. Frankie looks bothered.
Referring to the small table.

content.text: Frankie and Derek burst into laughter.

dialogue: I am what I am. But at least my mom doesn’t think I’m a serial killer.

content.text: Derek and Frankie stop laughing abruptly.

content.text: Drew pauses, looking at them then pushes back his chair.

content.text: Derek sits there shaking his head angrily.

dialogue: You don’t need him bro. You got me.

content.text: Frankie smiles and holds his arms out wide. Derek cracks a smile.
Frankie grabs his bag and begins feeling through it. He pulls out two different prescriptions. One is nearly filled to the top while the other is half full.

dialogue: What do they have you taking?
Just something for occasional pain and headaches.
(holds up the bottle that’s half full)
They said the headaches should go away eventually.
That’s cool. What about the other medication? The one that’s filled up?
Oh that’s some type of mood stabilizer, whatever that means. I don’t remember but my mom said I’ve been on these things since I was a kid. Apparently I had some anger issues. But between you and me,
I think the doctors are trying to poison my mind - and I’m not gonna let them- you know?

content.text: Derek seems a little surprised.

dialogue: Nothing. I didn’t know. Why do you think the doctors are trying to poison you?

content.text: Frankie smirks as he leans in closer to Derek.

dialogue: Bro, forget about them. I don’t need that shit or their opinions. I stopped taking those bullshit meds my first day back to school. I don’t feel like myself when I’m on ‘em. Ya know?
How do you feel now? Stable?
I feel great dude. Look at me.

content.text: Frankie leans back in his chair and spreads out his arms.
Derek gets on board.

dialogue: You’re absolutely right bro. Fuck those pills. I definitely like this version of you best. Matter of fact, give me the pills.

content.text: Frankie raises an eyebrow. He hands the filled bottle to Derek.

dialogue: Motives are a funny thing, ulterior or not.

content.text: Derek takes them from Frankie’s hand. He gets up and walks over to the trash can.

dialogue: We may not always see it in the moment but eventually our reasons surface.

content.text: Derek hovers the prescription over the trash can then looks at Frankie. Frankie gives him a nod of approval. Derek tosses the pills in the trash.

dialogue: Even without premeditation, if we’re not careful, eventually what personally benefits us colors our every move...

content.text: As Derek walks back over to their table Frankie LAUGHS and APPLAUDS him.

dialogue: Excellent dude. I love it. This is why we’re buds. We’re the same you and me.

content.text: Frankie smiles and nods.
A beat.

dialogue: Can I ask you a question Frankie?
If you found out someone who was supposed to be close to you betrayed you, could you forgive them?
Bro. Someone truly close to you wouldn’t betray you. They just wouldn’t do that. Like me and you for example.
I would never betray you and you would never betray me; right?

content.text: In the background Brad enters the coffee shop.

dialogue: Oh yeah. Of course. I agree. I was just curious how you saw it.

content.text: Derek seems strongly bothered but tries not to show it. Frankie is busy taking his pain pills. Then he closes the cap and puts the prescription in his bag. When he looks back up Derek is looking off. There’s a moment of silence. Then:
Brad walks up from behind Frankie. He looks angry.
Frankie turns to him.

dialogue: I’m kind of in the middle of something bro--
Frankie, I need to talk to you.

content.text: Frankie looks back at Derek. Derek gives him the okay with a nod of his head.
Frankie follows Brad as he leads the way towards the door.
Frankie and Brad stand face to face. Derek watches them through the glass windows.

dialogue: Alright, I wanna know what the hell’s going on?

We were best friends before your accident, now we don’t even speak. When you first came back I thought I’d give you some time because you didn’t really remember me, but now it’s like you do remember and don’t give a shit?
Look Brad, I’ve known Derek for a long time and our friendship is finally back on track.
Your friendship? Back on track!? You didn’t even give a fuck about that guy before! Now all of a sudden you’re besties? It doesn’t make sense.

content.text: Frankie genuinely laughs. Brad becomes infuriated.

dialogue: It doesn’t have to make any fucking sense to you. Now that I’m back to myself, I see how much of a waste of time you’ve been. You’re a fucking loser. Shit changes, what more can I say?

content.text: Frankie turns and Brad pushes him from behind. In the background, Derek rises to his feet and heads towards them. Frankie turns around and gets in Brad’s face smiling like a mad man.

dialogue: What the fuck you gonna do about it?

content.text: Derek steps outside and stands beside Frankie. Brad looks at them angrily.

dialogue: You guys gonna jump me or what?

content.text: Brad shoves his way through Frankie and Derek. Frankie and Derek stand there for a moment, eyes remaining on Brad.

dialogue: I’m gonna bounce. I’ll hit you up later.
Cool. I need to clear my head anyway.

content.text: They exchange looks of frustration.
They exchange fist bumps before Frankie walks off.

content.text: With a concerned smile, Brenda turns toward the ambulance doors. Derek sits inside bandaged up when she gets in with him.
Brenda smiles.

dialogue: The paramedic says it went all the way through, so it’ll heal nicely. So no cool scar, unfortunately.
I just wanted to apologize for everything Derek. I should’ve trusted you, and I didn’t. You were right about Frankie.
It’s okay mother. No harm no foul. Well, some harm.

content.text: CUT TO:
Jewels lays on a stretcher in an ambulance whimpering while the paramedic shuffles through medical supplies with his back to her when Sheriff Carter walks up with empathy.
Jewels looks at him, stops crying for a moment, then begins crying again.
Sheriff Carter gently takes her hand, looking her in her bloodshot, teary eyes, and speaks.

dialogue: I’m here. I’m not going anywhere.

content.text: CLOSE ON Jewels squeezing his hand
She takes a deep breath and exhales, trying to smile.
DISSOLVE TO:
LEGEND OVER IMAGE: ONE MONTH LATER
Derek and Brenda are loading the car with luggage, exchanging smiles from opposite sides of the car for the first time in a while.
Standing next to the car with the doors open, Derek and Brenda have a moment, gazing back at one another over the top of the car before getting in.
CLOSE ON Brenda’s face. She looks happy.

dialogue: This road trip will be good for us.

content.text: CLOSE ON Derek’s face smiling and nodding in agreement.

dialogue: We’ve come a long way Mother.
And it hasn’t been easy, but believe it or not... everything’s turned out exactly as planned.
Everything happens for a reason right?

content.text: Short beat.
Brenda continues smiling as they both get in the car.
DISSOLVE TO:
CAR - RURAL ROAD - MOMENTS LATER
From a high ariel view we see their car driving down a road with woods on each side. It’s beautiful like something on a postcard.
Up ahead there’s a street coming up but they drive right by.
INSIDE THE CAR
Derek reacts with a smile but keeps his eyes on the road.
Brenda frowns with confusion.

dialogue: You know, I’ll admit there were times I wasn’t sure I’d be able to pull all this off.
Pull all what... What are you talking about? That was our turn back there... And why did you call me Brenda?
That’s your name, right? Just calling you by your name Brenda.
Stop it Derek. What’s wrong with you? Everything was going so well--
Like I said, everything’s going as planned.
You’re a liar. And a thief.
What? That’s not true. Why would you say that?

content.text: Derek shakes his head through a deep breathe with an angry smile on his face.
Beat

dialogue: It’s amazing what you can find on the internet these days.

content.text: The scene fades to
DISSOLVE TO:
I/E. LOCATIONS - VARIOUS - DAY/NIGHT
MONTAGE:
-Derek reading a book on Hereditary Behavior then on his laptop screen in the search bar: HOW TO TRACE DNA LINEAGE

dialogue: I always wondered why I felt so different.

content.text: -Derek rummaging through old paperwork and medical records in a shoe box. CLOSE ON Derek’s birth certificate. REVEAL: Stacy Monroe listed as parent.

dialogue: JEFF said I’ll see her over his dead body. He said she’s sick.

content.text: -Derek arguing with his dad/Jeff in the kitchen. His dad turns his back and Derek grabs a knife from the counter and begins brutally stabbing him in the back repeatedly.
-Derek standing outside a maximum security, gate enclosed building
-Derek and Frankie at Derek’s hiding place in the woods. Derek hands off the coffee can of souvenirs to Frankie.

dialogue: I never wanted to involve Frankie, but... like you said, everything happens for a reason, right?

content.text: -A masked assailant kneeling with a bloody female corpse in what looks to be her home. The assailant pulls off mask.
REVEAL: Derek staring at the body, seeming fascinated by his work.
END OF MONTAGE
CLOSE ON Brenda’s teary eyes.
Derek continues driving with his eyes forward, not even glancing in Brenda’s direction as she cries.

dialogue: I killed them all... Well, except Brad and Drew of course...
I told myself it was, just practice. Working my way up to you.

content.text: Derek smiles, still facing forward.
Smiling big, Derek finally begins to turn toward Brenda only to see
DEREK’S POV: Brenda’s FOOT coming at his face as her back presses against her passenger side door. She kicks him in the face repeatedly as he tries to block her attacks.
The car fish tales out of control, sending them tumbling down the road violently.
CUT TO:
CLOSE ON medical machines BEEPING.

dialogue: This one’s lucky to be alive.
If you’d seen the car you’d call it a miracle.

content.text: We pan from medical machines to the IV bag, then follow the IV down to the arm it’s connected to.

dialogue: I was told there was another passenger?

content.text: CLOSE ON Sheriff Carter. He looks upset.

dialogue: Yea, that one’s at another hospital.
That’s a tough son of a bitch right there.

content.text: Sheriff Carter has a look of seriousness on his face.

dialogue: Anyway Doc, go ahead. I’m good here.

content.text: We hear the doctor leave, closing the door behind him.
ZOOM OUT
Sheriff Carter turns toward the hospital bed
REVEAL: Brenda lying in bed with cuts on her face and bruising. She’s unconscious.
CLOSE ON Sheriff Carter’s face. He lets a smile peak out just briefly.
DISSOLVE TO:

The walls, floor, and ceiling are all a gloomy, dingy gray. The room is clean, quiet and nearly empty with Brenda sitting at a small table across from a scraggly worn down woman with crazy messy hair in her face.
Her hands are under the table as she rocks in her seat.
Brenda still has light bruising and a small bandage on her cheek.
Brenda is crying.

dialogue: It’s over now. And I don’t know how to feel.

Erasing memories doesn’t change what happened and hiding the truth doesn’t last forever. It’s a Band- Aid on a gunshot wound. It may stop the bleeding for a second or two. But... Ultimately, it won’t hold.

content.text: The woman stops rocking in her seat.
She leans in to Brenda slightly and speaks.
CLOSE ON the woman’s face as she moves a strand of hair to
REVEAL: Hand cuffs and a missing ring finger.
The woman holds her stare for a beat.

dialogue: Doesn’t matter now... He doesn’t remember.

content.text: Brenda Shrugs her shoulders.
DISSOLVE TO:

scene_info.location: MAXIMUM SECURITY FACILITY - HALLWAY - AT THE

content.text: A muscular male nurse walks down the hallway alone, pushing a cart with patient prescriptions. It’s clean, quiet and vacant as we travel through the hallway passing doors to patient rooms on each side. After several turns through the hallways the nurse stops at a door, takes out his keys, unlocks it and walks in.
There’s someone lying in bed with his back to us.

scene_info.location: MAXIMUM SECURITY FACILITY - HALLWAY - AT THE

dialogue: So much can happen. So many hurt...

content.text: The person in bed turns over to
REVEAL: Derek with a large head wrapped bandgage and bruising on his face.

dialogue: Then just like that, it’s gone... Clean slate.

content.text: CLOSE ON Derek’s face seeming confused and frightened.

dialogue: I wanna talk to my mom and dad.
